CatDescriptText: William Ethridge, steelworker, 17 Elmore Street and Edith Purter, Hill District, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, February 20, 1960, pg. A1 with question: "Do you believe in the old-fashioned "woodshed" reprimand or the "talking things over with the offender" type of discipline as regards the correction of youngsters guilty of misdemeanors?" Mr. Ethridge's answer reads: "I believe in talking it over because some children cant' stand punishment."  Ms. Purter's answer reads: " I don't think that bearings do any good at all.  The parents should talk things over."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of William Ethridge wearing tweed overcoat, light colored hat with dark band, and eyeglasses, standing on sidewalk, Downtown; Portrait of Edith Purter wearing light colored leather coat with dark plush lining and suede gloves, standing in front of ribbed metal wall
